arguments.claim: Art. 133 wide enough to cover civil proceedings in High Court extraordinary jurisdiction if civil right decided.

holdings.text: Art. 133 is wide enough to take in civil proceedings decided in the High Court in the exercise of the extraordinary jurisdiction provided some civil right of the party is decided.

anchor.surface_text: There is companysiderable force in the submissions. As pointed out in the earlier case Art. 133 is wide enough to take in civil proceedings decided in the High Court in the exercise of the extraordinary jurisdiction provided some civil right of the party is decided.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Following precedent in Ramesh case, Article 133 encompasses writ proceedings under extraordinary jurisdiction where civil rights are determined.

holdings.text: The writ petitions challenging the Act affected civil rights in properties valued well over Rs. 20,000; the High Court could not refuse the certificate under Art. 133(1)(a).

anchor.surface_text: The appellants before the High Court were attempting to save their property by challenging the validity of the Act and the decision of the Court that the Act was valid directly affected the civil rights of the parties in properties well over the mark in value. In these circumstances, the High Court companysld number refuse the certificate.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applied Ramesh principle to facts: challenge to Act's validity directly impacted property rights exceeding valuation threshold.

holdings.text: The Maharashtra Agricultural Lands (Ceilings on Holdings) Act, 1961 is intra vires, included in the Ninth Schedule, and protected by Art. 31B.

anchor.surface_text: Since then on April 10, 1968, in State of Maharashtra etc. v. Madhavrao Damodar Patilchand and Ors. etc this Court has held the Act to the intra vires and the Act is also included in the 9th Schedule and is protected by Art. 31-B of the Constitution.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Following binding precedent of this Court in Madhavrao case upholding the Act against constitutional challenges.

holdings.text: Although certificate should have been granted, remand to High Court is futile as appeals on merits would fail due to subsequent upholding of the Act; appeals dismissed to save circuity of action.

anchor.surface_text: We would have, therefore, seriously companysidered remanding the case to the High Court for the grant of a certificate but for two things. Special leave was granted on May 5, 1966. Since then on April 10, 1968... It will be an exercise in futility to ask the High Court to certify the cases when the appeals that will follow must necessarily and inevitably fail. It is better to save circuitry of action and to dismiss the appeals before us.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Technical entitlement to certificate accepted but discretion under Art. 136 exercised to dismiss given supervening precedent rendering merits hopeless; avoids unnecessary proceedings.
